{{good article}} {{Infobox hurricane impact | Name=[[Hurricane Katrina]] | Type=hurricane | Year=2005 | Basin=Atl | Image location=Katrina Florida landfall.jpg | Image name=Radar image of Hurricane Katrina approaching southern [[Florida]] | Formed= | Dissipated= | 1-min winds=70 | Gusts= | Damages=623 | Fatalities=6 direct, 8 indirect | Areas=Southern [[Florida]],
[[Florida Panhandle]] | Rainfall=16.43 | Hurricane season=[[2005 Atlantic hurricane season]] }} The '''effects of [[Hurricane Katrina]] in Florida''' were in both in the [[South Florida|southern portion]] of the state and in the [[Florida Panhandle|panhandle]]. After developing on August 23, Katrina made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] near the border of [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] and [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] counties with {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} winds on August 25. While it was crossing the state, the hurricane's convection was asymmetrical, primarily located to the south and east of the center. As a result, high rainfall totals occurred in the [[Miami, Florida|Miami]] area, peaking at {{convert|16.43|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Perrine, Florida|Perrine]]. The rains caused flooding, and the combination of rains and winds downed trees and power lines, leaving 1.4 million people without power. Damage in South Florida was estimated at $523 million (2005 [[United States dollar|USD]]), mostly as a result of crop damage. Further south, the hurricane spawned a tornado in the [[Florida Keys]]. In the island chain, Katrina dropped heavy rainfall and gusty winds. After emerging from the state, Katrina intensified into one of the [[List of most intense tropical cyclones|strongest Atlantic hurricanes]], becoming a [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5]] on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]]. It moved ashore in [[Louisiana]] and [[Mississippi]], although the hurricane's outer periphery produced a {{convert|5.37|ft|m|abbr=on}} [[storm surge]] in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] along the panhandle. High waves caused beach erosion and closed nearby roadways. There were five tornadoes in northwestern Florida. Damage was estimated along the panhandle at $100 million. Throughout the state, the hurricane killed 14 people, of which 6 were directly related to the storm's effects. Due to damage from Katrina, 11 [[List of counties in Florida|Florida counties]] were declared federal disaster areas. ==Background== [[File:Hurricane Katrina August 25 2005.jpg|left|thumb|Satellite image of Hurricane Katrina approaching Florida]] Hurricane Katrina developed as Tropical Depression Twelve over the [[Bahamas]] on August 23, partially from the remains of [[Tropical Depression Ten (2005)|Tropical Depression Ten]]. As it moved slowly northwestward, it developed organized [[convection (meteorology)|convection]], or thunderstorms, and it intensified into a tropical storm on August 24. A building [[ridge (meteorology)|ridge]] turned Katrina to the west,{{cite report|author=Richard Knabb, Jamie Rhome, and Daniel Brown|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|date=2005-12-20|title=Hurricane Katrina Tropical Cyclone Report|accessdate=2012-04-07|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/TCR-AL122005_Katrina.pdf|format=PDF}} bringing it over the [[Gulf Stream]]. With warm waters and favorable [[outflow (meteorology)|outflow]], the storm continued strengthening.{{cite report|author=Stacy Stewart|date=2005-08-25|title=Tropical Storm Katrina Discussion Eight|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2012-04-07|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2005/dis/al122005.discus.008.shtml?}} At around 2100 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on August 25, Katrina attained hurricane status, based on observations from the [[Hurricane Hunters]].{{cite report|author=Stacy Stewart|date=2005-08-25|title=Hurricane Katrina Discussion Nine|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2012-04-07|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2005/dis/al122005.discus.009.shtml?}} Intensification of the ridge to its north caused the hurricane to turn to the west-southwest, and as it approached the Florida coastline Katrina developed a well-defined [[eye (cyclone)|eye]]. At 2230 UTC on August 25, Katrina made landfall near the border of [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] and [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] counties with winds of around {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The hurricane moved southwestward and crossed Florida in about six hours, during which its eye became better defined. During its passage, northerly [[wind shear]] shifted the deepest convection to the south and east of the center, and Katrina briefly weakened to a tropical storm before emerging into the [[Gulf of Mexico]] early on August 26. After emerging from the state, Katrina intensified into one of the [[List of most intense tropical cyclones|strongest Atlantic hurricanes]], becoming a [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5]] on the [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]]. Katrina ultimately moved ashore in southeastern Louisiana on August 29, where it caused severe storm surge flooding and catastrophic damage; it dissipated the following day. In the preceding 2004 season, Florida was affected by four hurricanes, including hurricanes [[Hurricane Frances|Frances]] and [[Hurricane Jeanne|Jeanne]] which hit [[Martin County, Florida|Martin County]] and caused billions in damage.{{cite report|author=Lixion Avila, et al.|date=2004-12-01|title=Monthly Tropical Weather Summary... Corrected|accessdate=2012-04-07|publisher=National Hurricane Center|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2004/tws/MIATWSAT_nov.shtml?}} ==Preparations== [[File:Katrina 2005 rainfall.gif|thumb|right|Total rainfall from Katrina in the United States. Data for the [[New Orleans]] area are not available]] About nine hours after the system developed on August 24, the [[National Hurricane Center]] (NHC) issued a [[tropical cyclone warnings and watches|tropical storm watch]] from the [[Seven Mile Bridge]] to [[Vero Beach, Florida|Vero Beach]]. Later that day, the watch was upgraded to a tropical storm warning and hurricane watch from [[Florida City, Florida|Florida City]] to Vero Beach after the storm's intensification became apparent. About 25 hours before Katrina made landfall, the tropical storm watch was extended northward to [[Titusville, Florida|Titusville]], and a tropical storm warning and a hurricane watch was issued for [[Lake Okeechobee]]. Early on August 25, a hurricane warning was issued from Florida City to Vero Beach and for Lake Okeechobee. In southeastern Florida, the lead time for the hurricane watch and warning occurred 31.5 and 19.5 hours before landfall, respectively; both were 4.5 hours less than the desired lead time. A tropical storm warning was also issued from Florida Key, southward through the [[Florida Keys]] to the [[Dry Tortugas]], and northward along the western coast to [[Longboat Key, Florida|Longboat Key]]. The warning in the Florida Keys occurred only nine hours before the onset of tropical storm force winds. On August 25, Florida's Emergency Operations Center was activated in Tallahassee to monitor the progress of the hurricane.{{cite report|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|date=2005-08-25|title=Officials Urge Preparedness As Katrina Intensifies|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/newsrelease.fema?id=18417}} Before Katrina moved ashore, schools and businesses were closed in the Miami area. Cruise ships altered their paths due to seaports in southeastern Florida closing.{{cite news|agency=Reuters|title=Hurricane Katrina drenches Florida|date=2005-08-26|publisher=Television New Zealand|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/411319/606925}} Officials in Miami-Dade County advised residents in mobile homes or with special needs to evacuate. To the north in Broward County, residents east of the [[Intercoastal Waterway]] or in mobile homes were advised to leave their homes. Evacuation orders were issued for offshore islands in [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]], and for residents in mobile homes south of Lantana Road. Shelters were opened across the region.{{cite news|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|author=Shadi Rahimi|title=Tropical Storm Becomes a Hurricane as it Nears Florida|date=2005-08-25|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/25/national/24cnd-storm.html}} Officials closed the [[Miami International Airport]], [[Fort Lauderdale – Hollywood International Airport]], [[Key West International Airport]], and [[Florida Keys Marathon Airport]] due to the storm. In Monroe and [[Collier County, Florida|Collier]] counties, schools were closed, and a shelter was opened in [[Immokalee, Florida|Immokalee]].{{cite news|author=Joseph B. Treaster and Shadi Rahimi|title=Hurricane Moves Over Gulf After Soaking Southern Florida|newspaper=New York Times|date=2005-08-26|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/26/national/26cnd-katrina.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2}} While Katrina was intensifying as a major hurricane on August 28, the NHC issued a tropical storm warning and hurricane watch from the Alabama border to [[Destin, Florida|Destin]] along the [[Florida panhandle|panhandle]]. The warning was later extended to [[Indian Pass, Florida|Indian Pass]]. Officials issued a mandatory evacuation for portions of [[Walton County, Florida|Walton]], [[Gulf County, Florida|Gulf]], [[Franklin County, Florida|Franklin]], and [[Wakulla County, Florida|Wakulla]] counties. ==Impact== Overall, Hurricane Katrina killed 14 people in the state, of which 6 were directly related to the storm. Six of the indirect deaths were in South Florida, of which three were from [[carbon monoxide poisoning]] caused by generators, one was due to a vehicle accident, one occurred during debris cleanup, and one was associated with a lack of electricity. At least five people were injured due to carbon monoxide poisoning. Overall damage totaled $623 million (2005 USD). ===Miami area=== [[File:FEMA - 27263 - Photograph by Marvin Nauman taken on 08-28-2005 in Florida.jpg|left|thumb|Tree damage in [[Dania Beach, Florida|Dania Beach]] in Broward County]] While moving across Florida, Katrina had an asymmetric area of thunderstorms, which placed the strongest winds and rainfall over Miami-Dade County. The highest precipitation total related to hurricane in the United States was {{convert|16.43|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Perrine, Florida|Perrine]], or about halfway between Miami and [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]].{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|title=Hurricane Katrina - August 24-September 1, 2005|publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]|date=2008-04-30|accessdate=2012-04-09|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/katrina2005.html}} Of the total, {{convert|15.10|in|mm|abbr=on}} fell in 24 hours. During its passage, the eye of the hurricane moved directly over the office of the National Hurricane Center, which reported a wind gust of {{convert|87|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The strongest [[maximum sustained wind|sustained winds]] in Florida was a report of {{convert|72|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on the roof of the [[Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science]] in [[Virginia Key]]. The same station recorded a gust of {{convert|94|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. Unofficially, wind gusts reached {{convert|97|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Homestead General Aviation Airport]]. The hurricane's accompanying [[storm surge]] was small, estimated at around {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}}. Consequentially, there was minor beach erosion and isolated coastal flooding. The heavy rainfall flooded neighborhoods in the area, damaging over 100 houses. The storm left about 1.4 million people without power in Palm Beach, Broward, and Miami-Dade counties. In [[Broward County, Florida|Broward County]] north of Katrina's first landfall, the hurricane dropped light rainfall, ranging from {{convert|2|to|4|in|mm|abbr=on}}. Downed trees killed three people in the county. Train and bus service was disrupted in the Miami area.{{cite news|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=New York Times|date=2005-08-27|title=Reeling from hurricane, Florida braces for 2nd hit|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/26/travel/26iht-travel27.html}} Property damage was estimated at $100 million. Widespread flooding affected crop nurseries and greenhouses,{{cite report|page=17|title= Weekly Weather and Crop Bulletin|publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]]|volume=92|number=35|date=2005-08-30|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/waob/weather_weekly//2000s/2005/weather_weekly-08-30-2005.pdf|format=PDF}} and crop damage totaled $423 million. Three people drowned in Miami-Dade County, two of whom on boats. ===Florida Keys and Monroe County=== Katrina weakened into a tropical storm while moving across [[Monroe County, Florida|Monroe County]]. Tides reached {{convert|3|to|5|ft|m|abbr=on}} in mainland Monroe County, which flooded several houses and vehicles in [[Flamingo, Florida|Flamingo]] in [[Everglades National Park]]. Most of the [[Florida Keys]] reported tropical storm-force winds. A station on Key West reported sustained winds of {{convert|61|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, with gusts to {{convert|74|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. While the storm passed to its north, the city reported a storm surge of about {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The storm's outer rainbands spawned an [[Fujita scale|F2]] tornado in [[Marathon, Florida|Marathon]] on August 26, which damaged an airport hangar and several homes. This was one of only six F2 tornadoes in the Florida Keys since 1950.{{cite conference|author=Kennard B. Kasper|title=A Climatology of Tropical Cyclone-Induced Tornadoes in the Florida Keys|publisher=Key West National Weather Service|year=2011|conference=24th Conference on Weather Analysis and Forecasting|location=Seattle, Washington|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://ams.confex.com/ams/91Annual/webprogram/Manuscript/Paper179677/KasperP471.pdf|format=PDF}} Similar to the Miami area, Katrina dropped heavy rainfall in the Florida Keys, reaching {{convert|10.05|in|mm|abbr=on}} in Key West. In the area, the storm left about 5,000 people without power. After Katrina re-intensified into a hurricane, a station on the Dry Tortugas reported sustained winds of {{convert|82|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, with gusts to {{convert|105|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. ===Elsewhere in Florida=== Light rains and winds spread into the [[Melbourne, Florida|Melbourne]] [[National Weather Service]] region. [[Kennedy Space Center]] reported wind gusts to {{convert|46|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, although there was no damage or erosion in the area.{{cite report|author=Spratt, Turner, and Cannon|publisher=Melbourne, Florida National Weather Service|date=2005-08-30|title=Post Tropical Cyclone Report... Hurricane Katrina|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/mlb/?n=katrina}} In southwestern Florida, the storm produced a storm surge of {{convert|1.13|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Clearwater Beach, Florida|Clearwater Beach]]. In the central portion of the state, some areas for pasture were flooded due to outer rainbands. ===Florida panhandle=== [[File:Katrina-14673.jpg|right|thumb|Roads covered by sand along the Florida panhandle]] After striking southeastern Louisiana, Hurricane Katrina made its final landfall in Mississippi, during which it produced a storm surge of about {{convert|5.37|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]]. The hurricane struck months after [[Hurricane Dennis]] affected the same area. In [[St. Marks, Florida|St. Marks]], the surge flooded several businesses, and in Walton County, high tides flooded several roads, including portions of U.S. Highways [[U.S. Route 98 in Florida|98]] and [[U.S. Route 331 in Florida|331]]. The storm caused moderate to severe beach erosion along the gulf coast, and washed sand onto many coastal roads.{{cite report|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|title=Photograph by Marvin Nauman taken on 08/31/2005 in Florida|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.fema.gov/photolibrary/photo_details.do?id=14673}} Winds along the Florida panhandle peaked at {{convert|56|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in Pensacola, with gusts to {{convert|71|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. High winds briefly closed the [[Interstate 10 in Florida|Interstate 10 bridge]] over [[Escambia Bay]] in Pensacola. The outer rainbands of the hurricane spawned five tornadoes, all of them weak and not very damaging. Rainfall along the panhandle reached {{convert|7.80|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Philpot, Florida|Philpot]], which caused flooding. The winds caused damage to some trees and structures and there was some minor flooding in the panhandle. There were two indirect fatalities from Katrina in [[Walton County, Florida|Walton County]] as a result of a traffic accident. Along the Florida panhandle, 77,000 customers lost power.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Katrina at a Glance|date=2005-08-31|page=4A|newspaper=Mobile Register|url=http://www.al.com/mobileregister/pdf/register083105a.pdf|format=PDF}} Damage along the panhandle was estimated at $100 million.{{cite report|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|volume=47|number=08|date=August 2005|title=Storm Data and Unusual Weather Phenomena with Late Reports and Corrections|accessdate=2012-04-10|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-9A9F03FE-85FE-4329-8843-6D145043E2C8.pdf|format=PDF}} ==Aftermath== On August 28, or about three days after Katrina struck the state, President [[George W. Bush]] declared a disaster area for Miami-Dade and Broward counties, which allocated federal funding for debris removal and other emergency services.{{cite report|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=2005-08-28|title=President Declares Major Disaster For Florida|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/newsrelease.fema?id=18459}} Three days later, Monroe County was also declared a disaster areas, and on the same day the three counties were designated to receive funding for public assistance; this included aid to repair roads and bridges, water control facilities, public buildings, and recreation areas. The declaration was determined after the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA) sent 20 State Emergency Response Teams to determine the extent of damage.{{cite report|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=2005-08-31|title=FEMA Expands Public Assistance For South Florida Counties Affected By Katrina|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/newsrelease.fema?id=18500}} After Hurricane Katrina struck the Gulf Coast, President Bush declared a disaster area for seven counties along the Florida panhandle on September 6; the counties were [[Bay County, Florida|Bay]], [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia]], Franklin, Gulf, [[Okaloosa County, Florida|Okaloosa]], [[Santa Rosa County, Florida|Santa Rosa]], and Walton. In addition, [[Collier County, Florida|Collier County]] in southwestern Florida was added to the list of disaster areas.{{cite report|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=2005-08-28|title=Public Assistance Expanded To Include Eight More Florida Counties |accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/newsrelease.fema?id=18644}} In the two months after Katrina struck south Florida, [[Hurricane Rita]] brushed the region in late September with tropical storm-force winds and flooding rains.{{cite report|author=Richard Knabb, Daniel Brown, and Jamie Rhome|date=2006-03-17|title=Hurricane Rita Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/TCR-AL182005_Rita.pdf|format=PDF}} In late October, [[Hurricane Wilma]] struck southwestern Florida as a major hurricane, affecting the Miami area with hurricane-force winds that left 98% of south Florida without power.{{cite report|author=Richard Pasch, Eric Blake, Hugh Cobb III, and David Roberts|date=2006-01-12|title=Hurricane Wilma Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pdf/TCR-AL252005_Wilma.pdf|format=PDF}} Including Hurricane Dennis in July, FEMA provided $1 billion in public assistance to Florida residents in association with the four hurricanes in 2005.{{cite report|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=2006-04-16|title=$1 Billion In Public Assistance For Florida 2005 Recovery|accessdate=2012-04-11|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/newsrelease.fema?id=25279}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Katrinaseries}} [[Category:Effects of Hurricane Katrina]] [[Category:Hurricanes in Florida]] [[Category:2005 in Florida]]

page.title: Effect of Hurricane Katrina on the New Orleans Hornets

revision.comment: /* References */
revision.text:
{{for|detailed information on the team's 2005–06 season|2005–06 New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets season}} [[Image:NO Arena CIMG6266.jpg|thumb|right|The New Orleans Arena in May 2006]] After [[Hurricane Katrina]] devastated the [[United States|U.S.]] city of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] on August 29, 2005, and caused extensive damage to the [[New Orleans Arena]], the [[New Orleans Hornets]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] were unable to play any home games there for the entire [[2005–06 NBA season|2005–06 season]]. They temporarily relocated to [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], becoming the '''New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets'''. After playing the majority of home games for both the [[2005–06 NBA season|2005–06]] and [[2006–07 NBA season|2006–07]] seasons at the [[Chesapeake Energy Arena|Ford Center]] in Oklahoma City, the Hornets returned to New Orleans for the [[2007–08 NBA season|2007–08 season]].
Following the success of the Hornets' tenure in the city, the [[Seattle SuperSonics]] [[Seattle SuperSonics relocation to Oklahoma City|relocated to Oklahoma City]] for the [[2008–09 NBA season|2008–09 season]], and now compete as the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2219124 | title=Stern: Oklahoma City top candidate if team moves | publisher=[[ESPN]] | date=2005-11-09| accessdate=2009-01-09 }}</ref>
==Response== [[Image:SuperdomeAfter.png|thumb|left|The New Orleans Arena at right following the storm]] Because of the extensive damage resulting from the hurricane, where the Hornets would play for the 2005–06 season came into question. Although the New Orleans Arena suffered only slight damage, the flooding surrounding the area made it impossible to use.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-09/02/content_474577.htm|title=NBA seeks relocation for New Orleans Hornets|date=September 2, 2005|work=China Daily|accessdate=2009-04-20}}</ref> With the [[training camp]] scheduled to begin on October 4, the team announced that the first three weeks of camp would be held at the [[United States Air Force Academy|Air Force Academy]] in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]], [[Colorado]], instead of their usual location, [[Alario Center]] in [[Westwego, Louisiana|Westwego]].<ref name="September 2, 2005">{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Jimmy | title =Hornets will train in Colorado Springs - Team could play season in Baton Rouge | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =A14 | date =September 2, 2005}}</ref> Additionally the team stated that they wanted to play home games within [[Louisiana]], at either the [[Pete Maravich Assembly Center]] or the [[Baton Rouge River Center|Rivercenter]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]].<ref name="September 2, 2005"/> On September 3, Hornets owner [[George Shinn]] stated that the storm would not be used as a reason to permanently relocate the franchise.<ref name="September 3, 2005">{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Jimmy | title =Shinn says Hornets won't leave in storm's wake | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =A14 | date =September 3, 2005}}</ref>
By September 10, the prospect of securing a Baton Rouge location to host the Hornets was fading as a result of the facilities being utilized for hurricane related relief operations. Numerous cities inquired about hosting the franchise for the season, including [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Oklahoma City and [[San Diego]].<ref name="September 10, 2005">{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Jimmy | title =Shinn: Hornets won't bail on New Orleans | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =A14 | date =September 10, 2005}}</ref> During this period, Oklahoma City announced that it was the favored choice to serve as the temporary home of the franchise,<ref name="September 10, 2005 OK">{{cite news | last =Lackmeyer | first =Steve | coauthor =John Rohde | title =Mayor: OKC is NBA's 'best option' | work =The Daily Oklahoman | page =A14 | date =September 10, 2005}}</ref> although by mid-September [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] announced that the New Orleans arena could potentially be ready for occupancy by the All-Star Break.<ref name="September 13, 2005">{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Jimmy | title =N.O. Arena 'not nearly as bad as Dome' - Hornets could play home games by All-Star break | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =A17 | date =September 13, 2005}}</ref> However, by late September the Hornets finalized a move to Oklahoma City, where 35 games would be played at the [[Chesapeake Energy Arena|Ford Center]] in Oklahoma City, as well as six in Baton Rouge at the Pete Maravich Assembly Center. Additionally, it was announced that three of the games in March could be moved to New Orleans if the arena repairs were complete.<ref name="September 21, 2005">{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Jimmy | title =The buzz is Oklahoma City - Hornets will play 35 games there, six at the PMAC | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =C5 | date =September 21, 2005}}</ref> At the same time, the NBA also announced the team would be referred to officially as the New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets, and that the deal reached with Oklahoma City would allow for the team to return for the 2006–07 season, if necessary.<ref name="September 22, 2005">{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Jimmy | title =Tale of two cities - NBA to recognize Hornets as Oklahoma City's team as well as New Orleans' | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =C5 | date =September 22, 2005}}</ref>
==Delayed return== In order to allow for a full recovery of the New Orleans market in the wake of the storm, the NBA announced on January 31, 2006, that the Hornets would remain in Oklahoma City for the [[2006–07 NBA season|2006–07 season]] and return for the [[2007–08 NBA season|2007–08 season]].<ref name="February 1, 2006">{{cite news | last =Reid | first =John | title =Hornets to stay in Oklahoma for 2006-07 | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =A1 | date =February 1, 2006}}</ref> The league also announced that New Orleans would play host for the [[2008 NBA All-Star Game|2008 All-Star Game]], in addition to hosting the team for six of their 41 home games during the season.<ref name="February 1, 2006"/> Although guarantees by the league and organization indicated a return for 2007–08, many fans in New Orleans were still skeptical of a permanent return due to the popularity of the team in Oklahoma City.<ref name="March 20, 2006">{{cite news | last =Lewis | first =Ted | title =Fans on guard | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =A1 | date =March 20, 2006}}</ref> Meanwhile, the Hornets opened their season in Oklahoma City with a 26-point win over the [[Sacramento Kings]] on November 1, 2005.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=251101003|title=Hornets build big lead, cruise to win Oklahoma City opener|date=November 1, 2005|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> They played their first game in [[Louisiana]] in a loss to the [[Phoenix Suns]] on December 21, 2005,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=251216003|title=Suns set over Hornets in Baton Rouge homecoming|date=December 16, 2005|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> and they played the first professional sports event in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina on March 8, 2006, where they lost to the [[Los Angeles Lakers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=260308003|title=Lakers top Hornets as pro sports return to Big Easy|date=March 8, 2006|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> The Hornets completed the 2005–06 season by winning 38 games, tenth in the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/standings?season=2006|title=NBA Standings - 2005-2006 |publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> They became the first team since the [[1974–75 Boston Celtics season|1974–75 Boston Celtics]] to play home games at four separate venues: the Ford Center, the New Orleans Arena, the Pete Maravich Assembly Center and the [[Lloyd Noble Center]].<ref name="April 14, 2006">{{cite news | last =Reid | first =John | title =Hornets' OKC experience better than expected | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =C1 | date =April 14, 2006}}</ref> The Hornets had finished last in attendance in the previous season in New Orleans,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/attendance?year=2005|title=NBA Attendance Report - 2005|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> but playing in [[Chesapeake Energy Arena|Ford Center]], they averaged 18,168 fans, a 78% increase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/attendance?year=2006|title=NBA Attendance Report - 2006|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> Referring to the fan support in Oklahoma City, Hornets star [[Chris Paul]] said that "You get a feeling you're a part of something special"; mayor [[Mick Cornett]] said "My expectations were lofty, but we've exceeded them".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2005_4016087|title=Hornets OK in Oklahoma|last=Blinebury|first=Fran|date=November 27, 2005|work=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref>
All repair work on the New Orleans Arena was finished by March 2006, and a new scoreboard and video displays were added during the process.<ref name="mediakit">{{cite news|url=http://www.neworleansonline.com/pr/releases/releases/New%20Orleans%20Arena%20Media%20Kit.pdf|title=All four top-seeded teams advance in New Orleans regional|year=2008|publisher=New Orleans Online|accessdate=2009-04-20}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> In June 2006, Shinn stated he was pleased with the ongoing recovery process in New Orleans and again reaffirmed his desire to permanently return for the 2007–08 season. However, the Hornets also announced that they were in the process of negotiating with Oklahoma City to play the 2007–08 season at the Ford Center as a contingency plan.<ref name="September 22, 2006">{{cite news | last =Reid | first =John | title =Hornets probing third year in OKC | work =New Orleans Times-Picayune | page =C1 | date =September 22, 2006}}</ref> The Hornets opened the 2006–07 season at New Orleans with a win over the [[Boston Celtics]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=261101002|title=Hornets sneak past Celtics in heartfelt opener|date=November 1, 2006|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> They improved their final record from the previous season by one game, and again finished tenth in the Western Conference, three [[Games behind|games out]] of the [[NBA playoffs|playoffs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/standings?season=2007|title=NBA Standings - 2006-2007|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> Their attendance declined slightly compared to the previous season, and they finished 15th overall in attendance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/attendance?year=2007|title=NBA Attendance Report - 2007|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> The Hornets made their permanent return to New Orleans on October 31, 2007, when they defeated the [[Sacramento Kings]] 109-90 to open the 2007–08 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/teams/schedule?team=nor&year=2008|title=New Orleans Hornets Schedule - 2007-08|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> In the two seasons since then, the Hornets have averaged an attendance of 15,574.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/standings?season=2008|title=NBA Standings - 2007-2008|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/standings?season=2009|title=NBA Standings - 2008-2009|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref> During the 2008 All-Star Game, the NBA donated $5 million towards relief work,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/trade-development/economic-development-urban/8896307-1.html|title=NBA All-Stars sink $20M into New Orleans recovery|last=Maloney|first=Stephen|date=February 25, 2008|work=New Orleans CityBusiness |accessdate=2009-04-21}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and staged an NBA Cares program throughout the city to help rebuilding efforts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/allstar2008/nba_cares/|title=Where Caring Happens: New Orleans|date=April 1, 2008|publisher=NBA|accessdate=2009-04-21}}</ref>

It was released on November 8, 2005 through [[Guttar Music]] and was produced by Myke Diesel. Released less than three months after [[Hurricane Katrina]], which impacted the group's hometown of [[New Orleans]], this album was dedicated to the victims of the disaster. ==Track listing== #"Intro"- 0:24 #"Them People"- 4:12 (featuring Yogi, Halleluyah & Jazzy) #"D-Boys"- 3:52 (featuring Halleluyah, Rowdy & Playa) #"1, 2, 3, G's"- 4:19 (featuring Black, Tank Dog, Yogi & Jazzy) #"That Work"- 4:45 (featuring Halleluyah) #"Streets Is Callin'"- 4:53 #"Real Talk"- 2:01 #"Hurtin'"- 4:08 #"We Don't Play"- 3:40 #"Jump Shob"- 3:57 #"You Don't"- 4:02 #"Go Head"- 3:57 #"Bounce Back"- 3:17 #"Bounce"- 3:21 #"Mob Life"- 4:30 #"Murder"- 5:02 [[Category:2005 albums]] [[Category:504 Boyz albums]] [[Category:E1 Music albums]] [[Category:English-language albums]]

[[Hurricane Katrina]] has been featured in a number of works of fiction. This article is an ongoing effort to list the many books, movies, television shows, pop songs and comics that feature Hurricane Katrina as an event in the plot.
==Books including Short Story Collections== <!-- alphabetical order by title-->{{citations needed|date=May 2012}} * ''1 Dead in Attic'' by Chris Rose * ''A Little Bit Ruined'' by Patty Friedmann * ''All Together Dead'' by [[Charlaine Harris]] * ''Babylon Rolling'' by Amanda Boyden * ''Blink of an Eye'' by [[Rexanne Becnel]] * ''City of Refuge'' by Tom Piazza * ''Darker Angels'' by MLN Hanover * ''Dogs Gone Wild: After Hurricane Katrina'' by Theresa D. Thompson * ''Down in the Flood'' by Kenneth Abel * ''First The Dead: A Bug Man Novel'' by [[Tim Downs]] * ''Hurricane Katrina--what Really Happened'' by Nathaniel Jones * ''Hurricane Song'' by Paul Volponi * ''Jesus Out to Sea'' by [[James Lee Burke]] * ''Last Known Victim'' by Erica Spindler * ''Life in the Wake: Fiction from Post-Katrina New Orleans'' by the writers of NOLAFugees.com * ''Lost and Betrayed (An American Tale): A Fictional Tale of Hurricane Katrina'' by Sly Fleming * ''Map Of Moments'' by [[Christopher Golden]] and Tim Lebbon * ''Misisipi'' by Michael Reilly * ''Murder in the Rue Chartres'' by Greg Herren * ''New Orleans Noir'' edited by [[Julie Smith (novelist)|Julie Smith]] * ''Nine Lives: Death and Life in New Orleans'' by Dan Baum * ''One D.O.A., One on the Way'' by Mary Robison * ''Revacuation'' by [[Brad Benischek]] * ''Rooftop Diva: A Novel of Triumph After Katrina'' by [[D. T. Pollard]] * ''Salvage the Bones'' by [[Jesmyn Ward]] * ''Storm Surge: A Novel of Hurricane Katrina'' by Ramsey Coutta * ''Taken Away'' by Patty Friedmann * "The Passage" by Justin Cronin * ''[[The Tin Roof Blowdown]]: A Dave Robicheaux Novel'' by [[James Lee Burke]] * ''Tubby Meets Katrina'' by Tony Dunbar * ''Voodoo Storm: Hurricane Katrina, Death and Mystery in New Orleans'' by Davis Temple * ''What Remained of Katrina: A Novel of New Orleans'' by Kelly Jameson * ''Zeitoun'' by [[Dave Eggers]]
==Non-fiction== * ''[[Pawprints of Katrina]]'' by [[Cathy Scott]], foreword by [[Ali MacGraw]], photos by [[Clay Myers (photographer)|Clay Myers]]
==Comic books and graphic novels == * ''[[A.D.: New Orleans After the Deluge]]'' by [[Josh Neufeld]]
==Film== <!--Alphabetical order--> * ''[[Déjà Vu (2006 film)|Déjà Vu]]'' (2006) * ''[[Hurricane Season (film)|Hurricane Season]]'' (2010) * ''[[If God Is Willing and Da Creek Don't Rise]]'' (2010) * ''[[Streets of Blood]]'' (2009) * ''The American Can'' (2011) announced{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} * ''[[The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (film)|The Curious Case of Benjamin Button]]'' (2008) * ''Waters Rising'' (2007), features criminal brothers from the [[Desire Projects]], whose lives are profoundly impacted by Hurricane Katrina and their evacuation to [[Houston, Texas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/waters_rising/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|work=Rotten Tomatoes|title=Waters Rising (2007)|accessdate=May 31, 2012|date=2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work=Yahoo! Movies|url=http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/waters-rising/|website=movies.yahoo.com|title=Waters Rising (2007)|date=2007|accessdate=May 31, 2012}}</ref> * ''[[When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts]]'' (2006)
==Music== <!--Alphabetical order, by song title--> * "God Forsaken Town" by [[Reckless Kelly (band)|Reckless Kelly]], off their 2008 album ''[[Bulletproof (Reckless Kelly album)|Bulletproof]]'' * The first verse of "Help is on the Way" by [[Rise Against]], off their 2011 album ''[[Endgame (Rise Against album)|Endgame]]'' * "My sanctuary" by [[Marc Cohn]], off his 2007 album ''[[Join the Parade]]'' * "Pontchartrain" by [[Vienna Teng]], off her 2006 album ''[[Dreaming Through the Noise]]'' * "This City" by [[Steve Earle]], off his 2011 album ''[[I'll Never Get Out of This World Alive (album)|I'll Never Get Out of This World Alive]]'' * "New Orleans" by [[Rancid (band)|Rancid]] off the 2006 album ''[[Let The Dominoes Fall]]'' * "Minority Report" by [[Jay-Z]] Feat. [[Ne-Yo]], off his 2006 album ''[[Kingdom Come (Jay-Z album)|Kingdom Come]]'' * "O Katrina!" by [[The Black Lips]], from the album [[Good Bad Not Evil]]
==Television series== <!--Alphabetical order--> *''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]'', [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]] (2006) (Season 1, Episode 19) (The Man in the Morgue) * ''[[Boston Legal]]'', [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] (Season 3, Episode 11) * ''[[Criminal Minds|Criminal Minds (TV Series)]]'', [[CBS]] (Season 2, Episode 18) * ''[[K-Ville (TV series)|K-Ville]]'', [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]] (2007) * ''[[Treme (TV series)|Treme]]'', [[HBO]] (2010–present)
==Theater== <!--Reads more like a marketing piece than an encyclopedia entry--> * The Hurricane Katrina Comedy Festival, by [[Rob Florence]], premiered at the 2010 [[New York International Fringe Festival]] at SoHo Playhouse. The cast, directed by [[Dann Fink]] and stage managed by [[Christina Lowe]], featured [[Philip Hoffman (Broadway actor)|Philip Hoffman]], [[Lizann Mitchell]], [[Maureen Silliman]], [[Evander Duck]] and [[Gary Cowling]]. The play interweaves the stories of five individuals in [[New Orleans]] during and after [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/arts/index.ssf/2010/07/drama_dead_in_heat_of_new_orle.html|title=Drama dead in heat of New Orleans summer? No way|date=July 24, 2010|work=The Times-Picayune|website=www.nola.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/World_Premiere_of_THE_HURRICANE_KATRINA_COMEDY_FESTIVAL_at_Fringe_NYC_813829_20100808|title=World Premiere of THE HURRICANE KATRINA COMEDY FESTIVAL at Fringe NYC, 8/13-8/29|date=Aug. 8, 2010|work=Broadway World|website=broadwayworld.com}}</ref> According to ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out New York]]'', the play focuses "on the kind of small anecdotes you might hear from a friend in your living room: politely amusing, occasionally moving, deliberately uplifting."<ref name=Feldman>[http://www3.timeoutny.com/newyork/upstaged/2010/08/fringe-festival-review-the-hurricane-katrina-comedy-festival/ "Fringe Festival Review: The Hurricane Katrina Comedy Festival"], Aug. 15, 2010, ''Time Out New York''.</ref> The ''[[New York Times]]''' David Rooney compared the play's narrative approach to [[The Laramie Project]], with the story told by each character "intertwined into a compelling chronicle,<ref name=Rooney>[http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/17/fringe-festival-journal-the-hurricane-katrina-comedy-festival/?scp=1&sq=Hurricane%20Katrina%20Comedy%20Festival&st=cse "Fringe Festival Journal: ‘The Hurricane Katrina Comedy Festival’"], David Rooney, Aug. 17, 2010, ''New York Times''.</ref> The show extended, and was included in the New York International Fringe Festival's Encores Series, remounted at the Lucille Lortel Theatre with the original cast, director and designers reprising their roles.
